parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "SLURM",
  "details": {
    "job_name": "imaging",
    "output_log": "data41_imaging_2_%j.log",
    "mail_user": "abulatek@ufl.edu",
    "mail_type": "END,FAIL",
    "nodes": 1,
    "tasks": 1,
    "cpus_per_task": 4,
    "memory": "40gb",
    "wall_time": "24:00:00",
    "qos": "adamginsburg-b",
    "casa_version": "/blue/adamginsburg/adamginsburg/casa/casa-6.1.0-118/bin/casa",
    "data_dir": "data_41",
    "field": "3",
    "frequencies": [
      "258",
      "259",
      "254",
      "255",
      "268",
      "270",
      "247",
      "249",
      "261",
      "263"
    ],
    "spws": [
      "69",
      "71",
      "85",
      "87",
      "89",
      "91",
      "105",
      "107",
      "109",
      "111"
    ],
    "imaging_script": "/blue/adamginsburg/abulatek/brick/scripts/imaging/imaging.py"
  }
}
```

The script uses **SLURM** (Simple Linux Utility for Resource Management) to manage the job execution on a high-performance computing cluster. The script requests one node, one task, 4 CPUs per task, 40GB of memory, and a maximum wall time of 24 hours. It also utilizes the **CASA** (Common Astronomy Software Applications) package, specifically the CASA6 version located at `/blue/adamginsburg/adamginsburg/casa/casa-6.1.0-118/bin/casa`. 

The script processes data located in the `data_41` directory for field `3`. It then iterates through a list of frequencies and corresponding spectral windows (`spw_list`), running the `imaging.py` script within CASA for each combination. The script logs the output in separate files named `casa_clean_ab_'$freq_num'_spw'$spw'_2sigma.log`.

The `xvfb-run -d` command was commented out, suggesting it might be used to run CASA in a virtual X server environment, which is not the case in the provided script.
